awd_titl_txt: EAPSI:EAPSI: Using Mass Spectrometry to Identify Protein Interactions at Fertilization
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the processes that occur during fertilization is critical for developing safe and effective contraceptives and for treating infertility. Much has been learned about these processes in recent years. However, despite these successes, our knowledge of what happens on the molecular level during fertilization and the initiation of embryonic development is limited. For example, it is not known what molecules on the surface of the egg and the surface of the sperm start the fertilization process and allow the sperm to fuse with the egg. This project will investigate these molecular interactions taking place between the egg and sperm in collaboration with Dr. Rommel Mathias, an expert in studying protein-protein interactions, at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia. The primary goal is in the identification of molecules on the surface of the egg that are required for sperm binding and fusion during fertilization.

In all animals, the initial conserved fertilization signal is a calcium wave that sweeps the entire egg. This calcium wave is initiated at sperm-egg fusion by a Src family tyrosine kinase and phospholipase C (PLC) gamma and it functions to both block polyspermy and initiate zygote development. The upstream protein interactions that influence the activation of Src and PLC are mostly unknown. Using a protein binding domain from the phospholipase C gamma enzyme, this project will identify proteins that interact with phospholipase C gamma during fertilization in the starfish. The starfish is an excellent model system for fertilization research because of the large quantity of easily accessible gametes, the success of in vitro fertilization, and the similarity of the known fertilization signaling pathways to that of humans. The Mathias lab specializes in viral-host protein interaction studies utilizing mass spectrometry and their expertise will be applied to identifying these fertilization-specific protein interactions using a state-of-the-art Thermo Fusion Orbitrap mass spectrometer.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
It is not well-understood in any organism what molecules from the egg and sperm are needed to initiate fertilization. If we know the specific molecules from the sperm and egg that are necessary to start this process, we can design more specific contraceptives, including more male contraception options, as well as provide targets for infertility treatment. This NSF EAPSI project focused on identifying important molecules involved at the initiation of fertilization in the starfish, Patiria miniata. The starfish provides an excellent model to study the molecular aspects of fertilization due to the ease of obtaining millions of viable sperm and eggs; their amenability to in vitro fertilization; and the known molecules involved in their fertilization pathway are similar to those found in humans. Much of the fertilization research conducted thus far has been with molecular biology and microscopy techniques. Through the NSF EAPSI fellowship, I was able to collaborate with a lab specializing in biochemistry and proteomic techniques to develop a novel strategy to identify more of the critical molecular interactions happening between sperm and egg to initiate fertilization.

The Mathias lab at Monash University in Melbourne, AUS specializes in using biochemistry techniques and mass spectrometry to identify important protein interactions between a virus and its host cell. Viral-host cell interaction is similar to the interaction between sperm and egg. Because the Mathias lab has been able to identify crucial interactions between the virus and its host cell, I aimed to adopt and implement their strategy to capture protein interactions between the sperm and egg needed to initiate fertilization. During my experience in the Mathias lab, I learned how to optimize the conditions for protein interaction experiments by choosing appropriate detergents for cell lysis, learned the most efficient method for isolating protein interactions, and developed the downstream statistical workflow for analyzing mass spectrometry data. Mass spectrometry is an extremely sensitive technique for identifying the amino acid sequence of proteins. Carefully designed strategies to capture protein interactions and statistical software aid in deciphering real versus false protein identifications in mass spectrometry experiments. Since returning to my home lab at Florida Institute of Technology, I have optimized the conditions for identifying important protein interactions at fertilization in starfish eggs. I am currently preparing more protein constructs to aid in the validation of real versus false protein identifications in these experiments for the eventual mass spectrometry analyses that will be conducted with the workflow developed in the Mathias lab.

The proteomics and biochemistry techniques attained from the experience in the Mathias lab were shared with my home lab at Florida Tech. These new techniques gained through the NSF EAPSI experience have been used to design a novel strategy to identify protein interactions needed to initiate fertilization in order to find new targets for contraception development and infertility treatment. Furthermore, the experience of collaborating with a lab in Australia to perform science experiments was also shared with the Boys and Girls Club of Melbourne, FL to demonstrate to middle and high school students the opportunities available through STEM careers.

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2018
Modified by: Lauren S Bates
